DialogueOption.Text: Uhhh Slate, I think the ship's computer is busted.
Did you finish fixing up the ship computer?
Uhhh Slate, I think the ship's computer is busted.
Did you finish fixing up the ship computer?
What if I don't know there's ghost matter somewhere?

Dialogue.Page: Stars above, your suit tells you when there's ghost matter anywhere nearby!

Your suit has a built-in sensor that should alert you whenever there's ghost matter nearby at all - and for the record, you should be wearing that suit for oxygen at all times off-planet - so it's basically impossible to just run into a patch without warning.
Once you know there's ghost matter around, use your scout to look out for it. You can even switch the scout to a handheld photo mode that lets you take pictures without launching it first.
I'd honestly be impressed if anyone died to ghost matter with all these tools - so stop worrying about the nebulous dangers of space and just take off already.

DialogueOption.Text: Uhhh Slate, I think the ship's computer is busted.
Did you finish fixing up the ship computer?
So.. Any reason you suddenly wanted me to remind me about problems in the ship?

Dialogue.Page: Stars above, how'd you even manage to break something in the ship already? What'd you break?
The ship computer? Gah, I hope it's not that piece of the museum statue in it malfunctioning..

DialogueOption.Text: Why's there a piece of the museum statue inside the ship computer?
Is the information in my ship log gonna be lost?!

Dialogue.Page: Gabbro chunked a piece of the Nomai statue in the museum while hauling it back. Hornfels took a look at it, and said it was some kind of stone that could store information.
It was just sitting around, so I thought it'd make a better component for data storage, than a museum exhibit.
Didn't think to stress test it to make sure it wouldn't get busted by idiots, though...

DialogueOption.Text: Is the information on it gonna be lost?!

Dialogue.Page: Uh, maybe?
Oh, don't be dramatic. Not like there's anything on it worth worrying about losing, anyway.. You've hardly taken off the planet!
Well, I dunno. Maybe you actually wrote down some spaceflight tips from Gossan. I guess we'll see how badly the data was hurt after I repair it.
Here, hand over your ship keys for a bit - I'm not letting you take me on a joyride while I'm working on the ship.
I'm closing the entry hatch too, by the way. You'll get blinded by sparks if you try to barge in while I work.

DialogueOption.Text: What should I do while I wait?
How long will I need to wait?

Dialogue.Page: Stars above, you aren't planning on just standing around until I'm done, are you? Go talk to the village before you take off!
Maybe ask the kids if they have any questions about the universe for you.
The kids in the village are always bursting with questions for the new astronaut on launch day. If you fire up their love for space, maybe one day they'll wanna join the space program too.
I should be done by the time you make a round around the village, so just go do something and stop bugging me.

DialogueOption.Text: Alright, I'll go talk to them.

Dialogue.Page: Sure did. It's working fine now.
Oh, and good news: whatever was on there should be just fine. The computer busted because some corrupted data was trying to upload, but I terminated that data.
Only odd thing is, I noticed a bunch of data already written in the ship log while fixing it up.
Probably don't need to ask, but.. You didn't write all those logs, did you?

DialogueOption.Text: Uh, are you talking about the ship logs to places I've been to?

Dialogue.Page: "Places you've been to"? Hogwash, hatchling. You forgetting today's your launch day or something?
Well, I'm just gonna assume that piece of Nomai statue in the ship computer had some secret data it wrote into shiplogs somehow.
Lucky you, I guess. Getting a whole Nomai tour guide to the star system in your ship computer on your launch day.
If you ask me, it'd be more interesting finding those places myself, though.
I mean, what's the point of exploring, once you know there's nothing more to explore?
Alright, enough talk. Here's your ship keys, hatchling!
Go fly that beauty into space - and go learn something new!
Hogwash, hatchling. You forgetting today's your launch day or something?
Well, I'm just gonna assume that piece of Nomai statue in the ship computer had some secret data it wrote into shiplogs somehow.
Lucky you, I guess. Got a whole Nomai tour guide to the star system in there now. Or unlucky, depending on how you see it.
If you're the adventurous sort, kinda takes the winds out of your sails, knowing everything about everywhere in the star system just like that, doesn't it?
Well, who knows. All you can do is hope that piece of Nomai statue doesn't already have the answers to everything, I guess.
After all, what's the point of exploring once you know everything, right?
Alright, enough talk. Here's your ship keys, hatchling.
Go fly that beauty into space - and go learn something new!
Cool, cool.
Just remember, there's five of those little squirts: Mica, Tephra, Galena, Arkose, and Moraine.
Oh, and don't forget to take the ship keys back from me later. Gonna be hard to take off without those.
Uh, I dunno? Pretty sure they're somewhere around the village.
Mica's probably still fiddling with the model rocket, just up the hill.
Tephra and Galena are probably playing in the village. Saw those two trekking outside the village recently for whatever reason though, so don't take my word on that.
Arkose's probably still throwing rocks into the patch of ghost matter at the top of the village. Still uh.. no idea why they do that all day.
And Moraine's probably stargazing on that big tree in the village, making sure Marl doesn't chop it down.
Just get a move on - you'll probably see all five squirts on the way up to the observatory.
Oh, and don't forget to take the ship keys back from me later. Gonna be hard to take off without those.
Hm? Oh, 'cuz I heard you talking in your sleep. Something you mumbled about the ship reminded me.
